data.title: Here are 50 of the greatest Louisiana high school athletes of the Title IX era
authors: Jimmy Watson, Christon Singleton, Emely Hernandez and Lamar Gafford, The Times
data.meta_description: Since Title IX’s inception, high school sports have seen a dramatic rise in girls’ programs and participation rates. Here are 50 Louisiana athletes.
data.text:
Since Title IX was signed into law in 1972, women have benefitted from the guarantee of equal opportunity for federally funded schools. Some of that opportunity has come in the form of sports.

In the 50 years since Title IX’s inception, high school sports have seen a dramatic rise in girls’ programs and participation rates, leading to successful college programs and new professional leagues for women and changing the landscape of athletics in the US.

Here’s a look at some of the greatest female athletes from the past 50 years in Louisiana high school sports, and why we celebrate them.

50 years of Title IX: How Title IX forced universities to get comfortable with women in the room

Katie Antony

Anacoco High School

The 2003 LSWA Miss Basketball and Gatorade Louisiana Player of the Year won five state titles in six varsity seasons scoring 4,447 points in her prep career. She played at Vanderbilt before transferring and completing her career at LSU.

Danielle Scott-Arruda

Woodlawn High School

The 6-foot-2 Scott played volleyball, basketball and softball at Woodlawn High in Baton Rouge before playing collegiately at Long Beach State. She would compete for the US in five Olympics, earning a pair of silver medals. She was the National Player of the Year and competed on the US Olympic volleyball team for 20 years.

Semoine Augustus

Capitol High School

An All-State guard for Capitol in Baton Rouge, Augustus was a 2002 WBCA High School All-American. A Wade Trophy winner at LSU, she led the Tigers to three NCAA Final Four appearances. The No. 1 pick in the 2006 WNBA Draft, she was a four-time WNBA champion and an eight-time All-Star mostly with the Minnesota Lynx.

Alana Beard

Southwood High School

The Duke and WNBA superstar led Southwood High in Shreveport to four consecutive state titles. Her Lady Cowboys won 53 consecutive games to close out her prep career. At Duke, she led the team to two NCAA Final Fours and was a four-time WNBA All-Star with one WNBA title as a professional.

Erin Blanchard

Comeaux High School

The Broussard native is a trampoline gymnast who represented the U.S. at the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing. She scored a 27.1 in her compulsory routine ad a 33.8 in the optional routine leaving her 13th overall.

Title IX pioneers: Sonja Hogg started Louisiana Tech program with $5,000

Emma Boozman

Winnsboro High School

A standout basketball player at Winnsboro High School, Boozman was part of history on April 5 when she was one of 10 women to receive the first full athletic scholarships to Northwestern State. She went on to coach Natchitoches Central to a state title while also winning championships at Campti. Her teams reached six Top 28 appearances.

D-D Breaux

Donaldsonville High School

Breaux was a nationally ranked gymnast and a Junior Olympic National Champion before heading to Southeastern Louisiana. In 1972-73, she was considered one of the top 15 gymnasts in the country. She coached LSU gymnastics for 42 years, compiling an 800-410-8 record with 35 NCAA Championship appearances.

Ashley Brignac

John Curtis Christian School

The River Ridge native was a two-time Gatorade Player of the Year and continued her dominance in the circle in college with 94 wins, 35 shutouts and 862 strikeouts. As a freshman in 2008, she earned a win over No. 1 Florida in the Women’s College World Series.

Kalani Brown

Salmen High School

The daughter of former NBA and Louisiana Tech player P.J. Brown, Kalani Brown had a stellar high school career and won Gatorade Player of the Year, two state titles and amassed 2,392 points, 1,471 rebounds and 605 blocked shots. At Baylor, she averaged 15.0 points and 7.7 rebounds and won a national title. Picked seventh in the 2019 WNBA Draft, Brown is playing overseas in Turkey.

Candace Carnhan

A.M. Barbe High School

She achieved national fame as one of the top softball pitchers the game has ever seen. Her 50 no-hitters and 393⅓ scoreless innings are still national records, and she led the Lady Bucs to three state titles from 1988-1990.

Emily Carter

Airline High School

An All-State player for the Lady Vikings, Carter had one of the greatest senior seasons in TCU women’s basketball history. She scored 20 or move points in five games, averaging 17.8 points per game. She connected on 60 consecutive free throws, the third best mark in NCAA history.

Vicky Chapman

Port Sulphur High School

She was the first star for McNeese basketball and scored 989 points (23.0 PPG) during the program’s first two years in 1974-75 and 1975-76. Still holding McNeese’s records for points (25.1) and rebounds (15.8) per game in a season, Chapman also played in the Women’s Basketball League for the Houston Angels and New Orleans Pride.

Pokey Chatman

Hahnville High School

Chatman is a native of Ama. She starred at LSU from 1987-91, starting all but one game and setting the all-time steals (346) and assists (570) records at LSU. She took over for longtime coach Sue Gunter in 2004, leading LSU to three consecutive NCAA Final Fours in 2004, 2005 and 2006.

Tazzie Colomb

Cabrini High School

An athlete in several sports, Colomb became one of the country’s top professional powerlifters and bodybuilders. She’s one of the longest competing IFBB female professional body builders of all time and one strongest female powerlifters in the world

'Fighting, scratching and clawing': Title IX equity in high school athletics still 'work in progress'

Baylee Corbello Cooley

Sam Houston High

A four-time LSWA All-State player in Lake Charles, Cooley won three state titles in high school. She went on to play three seasons at LSU before finishing her career in her hometown at McNeese State.

Meredith Duncan

Byrd High School

Duncan became one of the best golfers Louisiana has produced. She won the 2001 U.S. Women’s Amateur Championship and consecutive titles at the Women’s Western Championship. At LSU, she was an NCAA first-team All-American while earning Dinah Shore and Nancy Lopez awards. After a career on the LPGA Tour, Duncan has coached the boys and girls golf teams at Byrd to multiple state championships.

Pam Kelly Flowers

Columbia High School

The retired girls basketball coach is widely considered the best to have played for the Lady Techsters. The 1982 Wade Trophy winner helped coach Sonja Hogg build the Techsters into a national power. The 41-year-old still holds multiple Tech scoring and rebounding records.

Cheryl Ford

Summerfield High School

A three-time WNBA champion with the Detroit Shock, Ford was a highly recruited 6-foot-3 cente. The daughter of NBA great Karl Malone, Ford was a 1999 WBCA High School All-American Game participant before signing with Louisiana Tech. She was a two-time WAC Player of the Year for the Lady Techsters.

Pam Cook Forrest

Mount Hermon High School

She was part of the first Louisiana girls basketball All-Star game, organized by her father in 1974. She scored 26 points and was the game’s MVP. Forrest was offered a scholarship to LSU and became one of the original four female student-athletes with scholarships to LSU before transferring to Southeastern.

Sandy Fussell

Assumption High School

The Napoleonville native returned to her alma mater in 1981 and over 35 years became the winningest high school volleyball coach in Louisiana history with 1,080 victories. She led the team to eight state championships (1990-92, 1997-2000 and 2009), numerous state runner-up finished and 28 district championships.

Title IX pioneer: How Louisiana Tech's Sue Donohoe shaped women's basketball nationwide

Marie Gagnard

Bolton High School

Gagnard and her sister, Alice, led Bolton to the Class AAA state tennis title in 1975 and became the first tennis scholarship recipient at Louisiana College in 1976. The Louisiana Sports Hall of Fame inductee has gone on to become one of the top tennis officials in the country and was the first Louisiana official to work a Grand Slam in 2010 at the U.S. Open.

Lin Gamble

Central High School

Gamble was a two-time Class C All-State selection at Central of Grand Cane before playing at Ouachita Baptist and in the Pan Am Games. She averaged 37.4 points for her prep career and averaged 48.2 as a senior. She was a three-time All-American at Ouachita.

Yvette Girouard

Comeaux High School

After graduating high school in Lafayette the year Title IX was passed, Girouard took her volleyball talents to then-Southwestern Louisiana. She started the softball program at Lafayette High in 1977 before becoming the UL Lafayette then LSU softball coach. Her career record at LSU was 526-171-1 record.

Danyele Gomez

Cabrini High School

The Metairie native starred at UL Lafayette from 2003-06 and is one of 13 NCAA softball players to hit at least 80 home runs – ranking 11th with 83. One of those home runs came as a freshman off Texas pitcher and Olympic gold medalist Cat Osterman. She also had the Sun Belt triple crown as a senior with a .442 batting average, 30 home runs and 68 RBIs.

Alyson Habetz

Notre Dame - Crowley High School

The Crowley native was a two-sport star for ULL, leading Lady Cajun softball to its first Women’s College World Series in 1993 and scoring over 1,000 points for women’s basketball. Habetz is now the associate softball head coach at Alabama, helping it claim the 2012 national title and the 2014 national runner-up.

Chelsea Hayes

Marion Abramson Senior High

The New Orleans native was a track standout at Marion Abramson before it was closed in 2005 from Hurricane Katrina flooding. After Hayes set eight school records at Butler Community College, she became a 14-time WAC champion at Louisiana Tech in the long jump and 100-meter dash.

Lea Ann Jarvis

West Monroe High School

An All-state player for the Lady Rebels, Jarvis became a two-time All-American at Louisiana Tech in 1984 and 1985. She won two world championships with USA Softball and was inducted into the Lady Techsters Hall of Fame. She was a softball coach at Texas State and New Mexico State.

Title IX pioneers: Former Tennessee AD Joan Cronan was inspired by sexist snub

Pat Jean

Opelousas High School

The Opelousas native is one of the greatest McNeese basketball players of all time with 15 school records to her name. Among those are 2,461 points and 1,571 rebounds, which rank in the top 10 of any Louisiana college player.

Margaret Johnson

Vandebilt Catholic High School

As a softball catcher in Houma (1980-83), Johnson was part of four state titles and a 112-1 record. As the coach for 24 seasons, she won seven state championships in 13 championship game appearances and complied a 617-115-11 record.

Sheila Thompson Johnson

Pitkin High School

Believed to be the first female prep All-American in state history at Pitkin, Johnson became a two-time All-American at Louisiana College. She holds the school record for career scoring with 2,659 points and she led LC to the national semifinals. She also served LC as athletic director becoming just the second Louisiana woman to obtain that title.

Temeka Johnson

Bonnabel High School

The New Orleans native starred with LSU basketball from 2001-05. She broke LSU’s career assist record and was a two-time All-SEC first-team selection and 2003 SEC tournament MVP. She played a long career in the professional ranks, including stints in the WNBA with the Washington Mystics, Los Angeles Sparks, Phoenix Mercury and Seattle Storm.

Title IX at 50: WNBA represents a 'new model of sports activism,' and research backs it up

Vickie Johnson

Coushatta High School

Coming out of the current Red River High School in the early 1990s, Johnson was one of the most highly recruited girls basketball players in the country and a Louisiana state champion in the long jump. She led the Lady Techsters to the 1996 NCAA Championship game before going on to an All-Star WNBA career.

Rachel Laurent

Vandebilt High School

The Houma native and track and field athlete was a six-time indoor and outdoor state pole vault champion in Louisiana. She won back-to-back Louisiana Gatorade Track and Field Athlete of the Year awards in 2006 and 2007. She completed in pole vault at LSU, where she was a four-time All-American, SEC Champion and five-time All-SEC selection.

Angela Self-Longoria

DeRidder High School

The DeRidder native holds the Louisiana College/Christian record for rebounds with 1,271 (11.1 RPG) for her career and was only 5-foot-7. She helped lead the Lady Cats to the AIAW Division II Final Four and a third-place finish in 1980.

April Malveo

McDonough 35 High School

Despite not having a throws coach in 1995 at McDonough 35 in New Orleans, Malveo caught the attention of the Louisiana Tech coaching staff. She would become a three-time NCAA qualifier, a nine-time Sun Belt Conference champion and a 14-time All-SBC honoree in the shot put, discus and weight throw. She also became an Olympic finalist in the discus.

Kim Mulkey

Hammond High School

One of the first girls in the country to play organized baseball with the boys, the LSU women’s basketball coach led Hammond to four consecutive state basketball titles and graduated as valedictorian. She would become the first female collegiate coach to win a national title as a player, assistant coach and head coach.

Queen Brumfield Nard

Kentwood High School

A reluctant entrant into high school basketball world in the mid-1970s, Nard quickly became a star once she made up her mind. She would go on to become a three-time All-American selection for Southeastern being a key component of SLU’s 1977 Association for intercollegiate Athletics for Women’s Division II Small College title.

Kim Perrot

Acadiana High School

An All-State player, Perrot starred at UL Lafayette and in the WNBA before dying of cancer in 1999 at the age of 32. The WNBA named its sportsmanship award the Kim Perrot Sportsmanship Award. She scored 58 points, the third-highest in NCAA history, for ULL in a game against Southeastern.

Theresa Plaisance

Vandebilt Catholic High School

Plaisance started at Ursuline Academy of New Orleans as a freshman and sophomore before transferring to Vandebilt in Houma for her junior and senior seasons. She helped Vandebilt win the LHSAA state championship in 2010. She was voted a 2010 McDonald’s All-American and two-time Gatorade Louisiana Player of the Year. She played four seasons at LSU and has spent eight years in the WNBA.

Budgets, benefits and Joan Cronan: How Title IX made the playing field more even for women

Janice Joseph-Richard

Peabody Magnet High School

The Peabody graduate was Louisiana College's first NAIA All-American in the mid-1980s and led the Lady Cats to the NAIA national tournament in 1985 and 1986 – finishing third in 1986. During her career at LC, she averaged 21 points, 6.8 assists and 6.4 rebounds – closing her career at a 25 PPG clip to rank third in the nation. Coached at Xavier (La.), San Jose St. and LC. She died in 2010.

Leigh Hennessy-Robson

Lafayette High School

Hennessy became a two-time mini-trampoline world champion in 1976 and 1978. Her athletic success helped her move into a career as an actress and stunt performer on both television and film. In 1978, she became the first athlete to will all three trampoline events at the US National Championships.

Courtney Blades Rogers

Belaire High School

A four-time LSWA All-State pitcher in Baton Rouge, Rogers went on to a phenomenal collegiate career at Nicholls State and Southern Miss. She set an NCAA record with 497 strikeouts in 1999 and twice led Southern Miss to the Women’s College World Series.

Ann Roubique

Redemptorist High School

The Baton Rouge native played softball and women’s basketball at McNeese, scoring 797 points on the hardwood and batting .439 with seven home runs in 1979. Roubique is now the coach at Cy-Fair High School in the Houston metro area and has two state titles (2008, 2010) to her name. She also coached WNBA No. 1 picks and All-Stars Nneka and Chiney Ogwumike.

Chanda Rubin

Episcopal High School

Rubin was a standout in tennis from an early age. She began competing internationally as a teenager eventually becoming the No. 2 ranked player in the world. She made the semifinals of the 1996 Australian Open and defeated world No. 1 ranked players Serena Williams and Martina Hingis during her career.

Taryn Terrell

Pope John Paul II High School

Before she became a WWE superstar, Terrell was a powerlifter and cheerleader at her New Orleans high school. A former TNA Knockouts Champion, Terrell had a 279-day reign, the longest in the title’s history until 2019. She’s currently an NWA commentator.

Kelsey Thaxton

Negreet High School

The Negreet native obliterated the General record books by becoming the first women’s basketball player in program history to score 1,000 points. Her 1,678 points are more than twice as much as any LSUA women’s basketball player and she holds game, season and career records in points, made shots and 3-pointers.

Title IX and race: Are Black women being left behind in the push for equity?

Angela Turner

Shady Grove High School

A graduate of the now-closed Shady Grove High school in Saline, Turner averaged 30.9 points and 15.1 rebounds as a prepster before leading Louisiana Tech to two national titles. She was valedictorian of her 1978 graduating class and was named Miss Shady Grove.

Sandi Clark-Webb

Oak Hill High School

Clark-Webb went 67-17 with 556 strikeouts, a 1.09 ERA and 35 shutouts during her time at LC. She led the Lady Cats to the NCCAA national title as a freshman and was a multiple-time NCCAA All-American and American Southwest Conference Pitcher of the Year.

Mikaylah Williams

Parkway High School

Already selected to a pair of U.S. Junior Olympic teams, Williams is a 4.0 student and the No. 1 women’s college recruit in the country for 2023. The 6-foot-1 guard lead Bossier City Parkway to within one win of the LHSAA Class 5A state title last season. She has narrowed her college choice to five schools including Duke and LSU.

Kim Marie Willoughby

Assumption High School

The Houma native made her Olympic volleyball debut in the 2008 Beijing Olympics. She competed in volleyball, basketball and track and field at Assumption. She was a two-time Louisiana Player of the Year in volleyball.
